step.context: \text{Is the following the right way to \\find \dfrac{dx}{dt}?}\\
step.tex: \begin{align} x &= \sqrt{a^{\sin^{-1} t}}\\ \text{Squaring both sides }\\ \Rightarrow x^2 &= a^{\sin^{-1} t}\\ \text{Taking log both sides}\\ \Rightarrow 2 . \log x &= \sin^{-1} t .\log a\\ \text{Diffrentiating both sides }\\ \Rightarrow \dfrac{(2. \log x)}{dt} &= \dfrac{\sin^{-1} t .\log a}{dt}\\ \Rightarrow 2. \dfrac{1}{x}. \dfrac{dx}{dt} &= \dfrac{1}{1 + t^2} . \log a . \dfrac{dt}{dt}\\ \Rightarrow \dfrac{2}{x} . \dfrac{dx}{dt} &= \dfrac{\log a}{1 + t^2}\\ \Rightarrow \dfrac {dx}{dt} &= \dfrac{x . \log a}{2(1 + t^2)}\\ \end{align}
step.reason: \text{Other than Chain Rule we have used the}\\ \text{fact that \dfrac{d(\log \theta)}{d\theta} = \frac{1}{\theta}}\text{ and }\dfrac{d(\sin^{-1} \theta)}{d\theta} = \dfrac{1}{1 + x^2} \\

step.context: \text{Similarly, is the following the correct way to\\ find \dfrac{dy}{dt}?}
step.tex: \begin{align} y &= \sqrt{a^{\cos^{-1} t}}\\ \text{Squaring both sides }\\ \Rightarrow y^2 &= a^{\cos^{-1} t}\\ \text{Taking log both sides}\\ \Rightarrow 2 . \log y &= \cos^{-1} t .\log a\\ \text{Diffrentiating both sides }\\ \Rightarrow \dfrac{(2. \log y)}{dt} &= \dfrac{\cos^{-1} t .\log a}{dt}\\ \Rightarrow 2. \dfrac{1}{y}. \dfrac{dy}{dt} &= - \dfrac{1}{1 + t^2} . \log a . \dfrac{dt}{dt}\\ \Rightarrow \dfrac{2}{y} . \dfrac{dy}{dt} &= - \dfrac{\log a}{1 + t^2}\\ \Rightarrow \dfrac {dy}{dt} &= - \dfrac{y . \log a}{2(1 + t^2)}\\ \end{align}
step.reason: \text{Other than Chain Rule we have used the}\\ \text{fact that \dfrac{d(\log \theta)}{d\theta} = \frac{1}{\theta}}\text{ and }\dfrac{d(\cos^{-1} \theta)}{d\theta} = - \dfrac{1}{1 + x^2}\\

step.tex:
\frac{dy}{dx} =\frac{ \dfrac{d(y)}{dt}}{\dfrac{d(x)}{dt}}\\ \\ \text{Substituting, }\dfrac{d(x)}{dt}\text{ and }\dfrac{d(y)}{dt}\text{ in the above}\\ \text{equation.}\\
\dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{- \dfrac{y . \log a}{2(1 + t^2)}}{\dfrac{x . \log a}{2(1 + t^2)}}\\ \quad\,\,\,=-\dfrac{y}{x}\\
step.reason: \text{For calculating }\frac{dy}{dx}\text{we just divide}\\ \frac{dy}{dt}\text{ by }\frac{dx}{dt}\text{(which we have calculated in}\\ \text{the previous steps).
